As the spire descends, Javownir opens the portcullis to release the shantaks in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}.

Finally, the PCs can pull the oubliette to the ground by hauling on its cables until the oubliette locks in place. To do so, at least three PCs must work together and succeed at three simultaneous @Check[athletics|dc:38] checks. If only two PCs work together, the DC of the check increases to @Check[athletics|dc:41]. Only a PC who is legendary in Athletics can perform the feat alone by succeeding at a @Check[athletics|dc:46] check.

Reward: Regardless of how they do so, reward the PCs 10 XP for finding a way to enter the oubliette. Pulling the oubliette to the ground without assistance is a Mythic Deed, earning the PC who accomplishes the feat 1 Mythic Point.

Minimum-Security.name: Minimum-Security
Minimum-Security.text:
C4. Minimum-Security Moderate 17

Clusters of what appear to be soap bubbles, the largest of which could contain a fully grown human, grow throughout this area. In the chamber’s southwest corner stands a marble column nearly fifteen feet high. Atop the column is a statue depicting a muscled, lion-headed man locked in battle with an enormous serpent.

C4. Minimum-Security Moderate 17

@UUID[Actor.T5IcN50iJw5Paf5N]{Disordered Axolotls (2)}

Creatures: The bubbles are more examples of the cells described in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}. Currently, all are empty, except two. Inside a bubble in the northeastern formation float two creatures that look like pink-and-blue axolotls. If the PCs approach, the creatures alternate between making playful circuits around their cells and tapping forlornly against the “glass” making up their bubble prisons.

Despite their cute appearances, both creatures are dangerous. While they appear to be puppy-dog sized amphibians, both are in fact animate nightmares, and the bubbles they’re trapped in have become unusually weakened. Any solid blow struck from the outside can shatter the “axolotl” prison. Alternatively, the two smash free as soon as it appears that the PCs are moving on to a different floor. Regardless, when they are released, each returns to their terrifying true forms: a 10-foot-tall distortion of axolotls whose limbs jut from their bodies at disturbing angles. These nightmares were spawned from a breakdown of law and order; if released, they use their Panicking Touch ability to sow confusion via its Disorder effect. The nightmares pursue the PCs throughout the oubliette; if they flee entirely, the animate nightmares wait an hour for their return, then abandon the oubliette forever.

Low-Security.name: Low-Security
Low-Security.text:
C5. Low-Security Moderate 17

More formations of organic-looking bubbles grow throughout this area. Several of the largest bubbles appear to have shattered, littering the floor with shards of broken glass.

The bubble cells on this level are identical to those on the minimum-security level, but many are broken. The few cells that remain unbroken are currently empty.

C5. Low-Security Moderate 17

@UUID[Actor.TYZkUOrgSNyMOFqp]{Aceta} @UUID[Actor.XEHXfbjA2ZeKb3LA]{Famine Bear}

Creatures: This level is currently occupied by Aceta, the youngest of the Bittersweet Sisters, who is here “playing” with an animate nightmare she released from one of the bubble cells. This nightmare was spawned from a fear of famine and is shaped like a grizzly bear with a fleshless skull. When the PCs arrive, Aceta has just finished “feeding” a hapless human traveler she snatched up from elsewhere to the famine bear, enjoying the fact that no matter how much the nightmare “eats” it never gets full. She attacks the party immediately, targeting them with spells as the nightmare rushes them. Once it looks likely the PCs are going to win the encounter, Aceta retreats (either via the shaft or, if that route is blocked, by Riding the Moonbeams) to alert her sister Raanka in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03highsecurity00]{C6}.

Maximum-Security.name: Maximum-Security
Maximum-Security.text:
C7. Maximum-Security Severe 17

The separator between this room and area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03upperpointun00]{C8} above is rotated, blocking easy access upward.

A single bubble, nearly thirty feet in diameter, rises from the floor near the western wall of this level. In each of the chamber’s four corners, portrait-sized mirrors balance on tripods made of polished ebony. Reflected in the surface of each mirror is the image of a moon hanging in the nighttime sky. The glow from these moons fills the chamber with silver light.

The bubble cell against the western wall contains a terrifying prisoner: an elite animate nightmare that formed when an entire world was torn apart by Yog-Sothoth. The cell’s magic barely alleviates the horror of this nightmare’s true form: a mass of writhing tentacles that mirrors Yog-Sothoth’s incarnation as the Lurker at the Threshold. Even the Bittersweet Sisters fear this nightmare, but in desperation, Spleen is trying to set it free (see Creatures, below).

The mirrors in the corners of the room belong to the Bittersweet Sisters, who brought them when they arrived here from Jandelay. Each mirror reflects the moonlight of the god @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.WloVxo6HXJdS4YTt]{Groetus}, who hangs like a skull-faced moon above the Boneyard. The mirrors shed this unsettling moonlight into their corresponding quadrants of the chamber, allowing the hags to benefit from their Moonlight’s Kiss ability. Each mirror can be shattered with a Strike or otherwise rendered inoperable with a single Interact action (by covering the mirror with a cloak, tipping it off its tripod, and so on).

Scene Notes Macros

@UUID[Macro.fWzVJ7SdTbyx4gN9]{Break Mirror NW} @UUID[Macro.KHlcG2iPwSG66hKV]{NE} @UUID[Macro.5NzmXSnIqYSuM5TX]{SW} @UUID[Macro.DPPYcjj5ZO4bW0Lx]{SE} | @UUID[Macro.hDQ04KCSfpRZiwqt]{Burst Bubble}

C7. Maximum-Security Severe 17

@UUID[Actor.EAtCrHLzlytvvVjL]{Spleen} @UUID[Actor.8tsFnx9wfP6JiSp2]{Lurking Cataclysm}

Creatures: Spleen, the eldest of the Bittersweet Sisters, is in this chamber working to overcome the bubble cell’s defenses and release the nightmare trapped inside. When the PCs arrive, she’s just managed to decipher a method of opening the bubble cell, only to realize that in doing so, she’s started a chain reaction that will cause the cell to burst. Three rounds after the encounter with Spleen begins, the nightmare within breaks free, attacking the PCs, Spleen, and any other creatures in the chamber indiscriminately.

In combat, Spleen targets the PCs with her most damaging spells. Once engaged in melee, she keeps to the areas of the chamber lit by moonlight from the mirrors, using the extra action granted by Moonlight’s Kiss to make claw Strikes. If one (or both) of Spleen’s sisters are here, the hags work together to defeat the PCs, and this encounter escalates to beyond Extreme, but the introduction of the disaster-themed animate nightmare could be something that tips the flow of the fight in the PCs’ direction.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.ZzemVlPly4XGJ0JP]{Mirrors} @UUID[Actor.45Zn7KrsIPG4lpiW]{Leather Thong}
Except for their ability to reflect the Groetus-moon, the Sisters’ mirrors possess no magical properties. Nevertheless, the mirrors can be sold as a curiosities for 1,500 gp each, provided they survive the battle. The ebony tripods on which the mirrors rest are worth 75 gp each. Strung on a leather thong around Spleen’s neck is the key that unlocks the masks worn by Javownir and Liralarue, as well as a fate tempter’s ring.

Upper Point.name: Upper Point
Upper Point.text:
C8. Upper Point Moderate 17

Normally, the shaft connecting area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7} and the oubliette’s upper point is a mere 10 feet long. However, the recent convergence of such powerful magic—including the arrival of the Bittersweet Sisters, Liralarue’s imprisonment, and the release of the various animate nightmares—has warped the length of the shaft, transforming it into an extradimensional space. To make matters worse, the maze-weavers from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2} have extended their extradimensional webbing into the shaft. Finally, the separator disk between the two areas is rotated, requiring the spindle key open it. Even with the oubliette properly aligned, the PCs must traverse the extradimensional space before they can reach Liralarue’s chambers. When the PCs first investigate the shaft leading to area C8, read or paraphrase the following.

Rather than leading to another chamber, the shaft opens into an endless black void crisscrossed with webs that stretch to infinity. The opening to a second shaft hangs above the void hundreds of feet overhead, though from this vantage point it appears no larger than a distant star.

C8. Upper Point Moderate 17

@UUID[Actor.LiQDLBP3kMT9oeP9]{Apocalypse Stormfront} @UUID[Actor.5R0z7j2nKVkBjF53]{Maze-Weavers (2)}

Hazard: To reach Liralarue’s quarters, the PCs must climb the maze-weavers’ webs while being buffeted by visions of Golarion’s destruction. When describing these visions to the players, try to pick locations their characters have recently visited or places that are familiar to them; as the PCs climb, they must watch helplessly as these beloved locations are destroyed before their eyes.

Note that the Apocalypse Stormfront is a nightmare hazard, as detailed in the article on @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22005terror]{Terrors of Leng}. Disabling the nightmare involves the PCs navigating and pushing through the eternity and torment it creates—by succeeding in the face of these visions and this eternal voyage, they can unravel the nightmare with their own convictions.

As long as this nightmare remains, the entirety of Liralarue’s Prison beyond remains impossibly distant at the far end of this void; only by disabling this hazard can the PCs progress. Once a creature enters the Apocalypse Stormfront, they can exit back into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7} by spending three actions to attempt a @Check[will|dc:41] save; on a success, they find themselves back, safe, in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7}. The number of successes the PCs accumulate toward the six required to disable this nightmare does not reset if they retreat from the Apocalypse Stormfront.

Creatures: If the PCs haven’t dealt with the maze-weavers in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2}, the spiders sense the disturbance of their webs in this area. One round later, two of the maze-weavers arrive, attacking the PCs as they climb. The spiders are immune to the effects of the Apocalypse Stormfront hazard, and their presence in the encounter increases the difficulty to Severe.

Reward: Reaching Liralarue’s Prison is a mythic deed; award each character 3 Mythic Points.

Liralarue’s Prison.name: Liralarue’s Prison
Liralarue’s Prison.text:
Liralarue’s Prison Trivial 17

Once the PCs disable the Apocalypse Stormfront hazard, they find themselves in the uppermost point of the oubliette. Javownir used this chamber as his home, but the Bittersweet Sisters ousted the denizen of Leng shortly after they arrived. The room now serves as a prison for the Sisters’ captive, Liralarue.

This chamber is shaped like the interior of a pyramid. The space is filled with modest but comfortable-looking furnishings, including a small dining table, a writing desk flanked by bookshelves, a wardrobe, and a pair of divans.

Liralarue’s Prison Trivial 17

@UUID[Actor.7EtywkFz8aRJB5Ap]{Bittersweet Mask}

Hazard: When the PCs arrive, they find a beautiful human woman dressed in gold and purple robes and armed with a naginata, at rest on one of the divans. This is Liralarue, and she wears a mask identical to the one worn by Javownir that must be removed before she can communicate with the PCs. Once the mask is off, Liralarue tells the PCs what she knows about Xanderghul’s plans to destroy Golarion (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03concludingth00]{Concluding the Adventure} below). While she can’t leave the Dreamlands, she can transport the PCs back to Golarion when they’re ready to continue their fight against Xanderghul.

Reward: For saving Liralarue, award each PC 80 XP.

Concluding the Adventure.name: Concluding the Adventure
Concluding the Adventure.text:
Concluding the Adventure

Once she’s been rescued and has time to speak to the PCs, Liralarue reveals that she has developed the power to see all possible futures but is cursed to never know which one is real. While she can’t say whether Xanderghul’s bid to become a god will succeed, she knows it was the Ashen Man who set the runelord on his current path. The Ashen Man helped Xanderghul escape from the Eclipse in Abaddon then showed him how he might offer the Saga Lands as a sacrifice and become a god worshipped on a brand-new world. The PCs prevented Xanderghul from expediting this process via the Doomsday Doors, but he hasn’t given up. Liralarue warns the PCs that Xanderghul has traveled to Jandelay to complete Golarion’s addition to that plane of destroyed worlds. Liralarue can’t exist outside of the Dreamlands, but now that the PCs have rescued her, she can aid them from beyond the wall of sleep as they take steps to stop Xanderghul’s plans. Except for being able to send the PCs back to Golarion from the Dreamlands when they wish, her aid truly begins with the start of the next adventure, so notes on her history and personality and the ways she can help aren’t presented in this volume; the next adventure will provide these details.

For now, though, the PCs have more than earned a chance to rest and recover from their adventures—at least until news reaches them that Runelord Belimarius has made her move in a brazen attempt to claim all New Thassilon for herself, as detailed at the start of the final adventure in the Revenge of the Runelords Adventure Path!

Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands.name: Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands
Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands.text:
Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands

Once the PCs have recovered (grant them all 3 Mythic Points as well if you’re not starting a new session at this point), it’s time for them to race against the Risen to save the Saga Lands. While each of the six groups seeking to open a different Doomsday Door are large, and each group is led by a level 11 risen runelord, the challenge of this event lies not in combat, but in gathering allies, deploying a plan, and then acting to prevent the opening of six Doomsday Doors before time runs out.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.C1Ayc4Kh3fh4Laxn]{Nature}

This event uses the Beat the Clock version of the chase rules (Pathfinder GM Core 192). Each chase round represents the work of several days as the PCs race across the Saga Lands to assemble their allies, organize a response, and travel to the Doomsday Door sites to stop Xanderghul’s allies from opening them.

The PCs can tackle the six obstacles in any order. The more Doomsday Doors the PCs close before they reach the end of round 6 of the chase, the more lives they save. Any obstacles not completed after the chase’s six rounds are up are automatically lost as the Doomsday Door at that location is opened, releasing a catastrophe that will burden that region for years.

Help from Allies.name: Help from Allies
Help from Allies.text:
Help from Allies

Before the chase begins, work with your players to generate a list of the allies they’ve made thus far in the adventure. These allies could include Ayavah, Elias Tammerhawk, Sheila Heidmarch, Toff Ornelos, Lograsi, Roaring Storm, and Knud Helmarsson. (If the PCs aren’t relying on the omen dragon Kandirvek for travel, he could be an ally as well.) This event assumes the PCs have at least six allies to call upon during the chase but not more than a dozen.

An ally must be deployed to an obstacle; once this is done, that ally cannot aid at other obstacles, and they reduce the Overcome DCs for the obstacle to which they’re deployed by 1, regardless of how long the PCs take to overcome the obstacle. These reductions stack if the PCs deploy multiple allies to a single obstacle.

Doomsday Door Obstacles.name: Doomsday Door Obstacles
Doomsday Door Obstacles.text:
Doomsday Door Obstacles

The PCs can attempt the following six obstacles in any order. Each obstacles has a sin trait—this sin indicates what region of Old Thassilon the obstacle takes place in, and thus whether or not a PC can apply their +2 status bonus for having a matching vengeance feat.

The PCs can also distribute their allies as they wish among these six sites and can continue to redistribute them among obstacles they haven’t yet started or completed. For each obstacle, two key allies are called out as being particularly useful. When one of these two allies is deployed to that obstacle, they decrease the Overcome DCs by 2 points instead of by 1.

For each of these obstacles, an option to use Arcana, Nature, Occultism, or Religion is presented. When a PC chooses to use one of these options, it’s assumed they’re using spells or magic to aid. While you don’t need to build an exact list of what spells and effects the PC employs, allow them to describe what they’re doing. If, at your discretion, the effort involves the expenditure of powerful and appropriate magic of rank 7 or higher, reduce the DC of that skill check by 2.

Jol Obstacle 17

  • Pride

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[survival|dc:38] to navigate sudden blizzards, @Check[thievery|dc:41] to disarm ancient traps, @Check[nature|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[occultism|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to fight the deadly weather with magic

The city of Jol is the capital of Southmoor in the Lands of the Linnorm Kings. Furious blizzards presage the opening of this Doomsday Door. Risen Runelord of Greed Fethryr leads this obstacle, as she and her cultists hunker down in the heart of a trap-ridden vault beneath the Skirim River where the Doomsday Door is hidden.

Key Allies: Knud Helmarsson’s familiarity with the terrain helps you navigate the blizzards; Sheila’s Pathfinders aid in disabling the vault’s traps

Failure: The southern Lands of the Linnorm Kings endure a deadly series of blizzards and storms. If the PCs fail to defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure, a land of eternal winter blooms across the borderlands here, allowing Irrisen to potentially expand their reach while devastating the economy of the Linnorm Kingdoms.

Korvosa Obstacle 17

  • Lust

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[athletics|dc:38] to jump, climb, and force open barriers, @Check[society|dc:41] to mobilize the city’s defenses, @Check[religion|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[nature|dc:46], or @Check[occultism|dc:46]) to deploy Korvosa’s healers

Disease spreads through the streets of the city, evoking panic and fear about a potential new outbreak of blood veil, the plague that nearly brought Korvosa to her knees years ago. Korvosa’s Doomsday Door lies in a long-forgotten corner of the Vaults, the city’s sprawling sewer system, in a dungeon that was hidden even from Runelord Sorshen. Risen Runelord of Envy Zarve leads this group of cultists.

Key Allies: Roaring Storm leaps across the rooftops without fear and both inspires and aids those who follow; the Acadamae’s wizards, led by Toff Ornelos, hold off the runelords while you press on to the Doomsday Door

Failure: A sudden resurgence of the supernatural disease known as blood veil sweeps through Korvosa, but this time it cannot be stopped, and it spreads throughout southeastern Varisia and into Nidal in a devastating pandemic if the PCs fail to defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure.

Old Xin-Edasseril Obstacle 17

  • Envy

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[diplomacy|dc:38] to navigate bureaucracy to reach the site, @Check[stealth|dc:41] to sneak into the area, @Check[arcana|dc:36] (or @Check[nature|dc:46], @Check[occultism|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to avoid remaining arcane wards

Edasseril’s capital was originally located on modern-day Chakikoth Isle in the Ironbound Archipelago, and its here in the depths of a series of caverns that this Doomsday Door lies. Reaching the ancient city requires navigating the nation’s byzantine bureaucracy as flooding and destructive shoreline surges increasingly panic the populace. Risen Runelord of Gluttony Goparlis leads the charge here.

Key Allies: Lograsi uses his influence with Belimarius to pave your way into the nation; Elias Tammerhawk enlists the pirate captains of Riddleport to sail you to Old Xin-Edasseril

Failure: A tsunami wreaks havoc on the coast, while torrential rainstorms cause inland flooding. Fears that the islands might be sinking spread, incidentally spurring Runelord Belimarius even further into expansion onto the mainland. The islands will indeed sink if Runelord Xanderghul isn’t defeated in the next adventure.

Sech Nevali Obstacle 17

  • Sloth

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[intimidation|dc:38] to hold your own among the nightmares; @Check[acrobatics|dc:41] to navigate narrow walkways, @Check[occultism|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[nature|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to disarm occult energies

Sech Nevali is a temple complex suspended over a chasm. Here, dreams and nightmares grow interchangeable with reality as a plague of horror made real seep out of the opening Doomsday Door. Risen Runelord of Envy Esedrea has forged alliances with the monastery’s graveknight guardians—former warriors of the Peacock Spirit.

Key Allies: Sheila Heidmarch supplies you with texts that include rites of protection from nightmare plagues; Ayavah draws upon ancient texts she’s studied about Sech Nevali’s artistry and architecture to help guide you

Failure: The nightmare plague spreads, and those who slumber and dream in the region must contend with the growing truth that death in a nightmare now equates to death in real life. If the PCs don’t defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure, this nightmare plague spreads swiftly through the Saga Lands.

The Sleeper Obstacle 17

  • Gluttony

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[performance|dc:38] to inspire allies, @Check[athletics|dc:41] to endure the grueling climb, @Check[arcana|dc:36] (or @Check[nature|dc:46], @Check[occultism|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to battle the magical wards that protect the Sleeper

A monument in the Hold of Belkzen, the Sleeper is sculpted to resemble a dragon wrapped around a mountaintop. You must inspire your troops to climb the mountain into the dragon’s maw, then cut down the undead hordes pouring through the Doomsday Door hidden in the deep cavern within the Sleeper. These hordes are commanded by Risen Runelord of Gluttony Aethusa.

Key Allies: Roaring Storm’s bravery inspires the troops forward; Toff Ornelos helps you to navigate the ancient magic found within the Sleeper

Failure: A horde of undead spills out of the Sleeper and invades the surrounding region. If the PCs don’t defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure, this invasion of undead from an unexpected direction throws the Hold of Belkzen into chaos and war

Windsong Abbey Obstacle 17

  • Wrath

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[stealth|dc:38] to creep behind enemy lines, @Check[intimidation|dc:41] to cow the invading fiends, @Check[religion|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[nature|dc:46], or @Check[occultism|dc:46]) to use magic to defeat the invading fiends

Located on Varisia’s Lost Coast, Windsong Abbey serves as a neutral ground where opposing religions resolve their differences. This Doomsday Door is located deep below the abbey and, upon arrival, you find the local priests fighting to hold off an invasion of qlippoth that have been seeping through the door below after Risen Runelord of Sloth Ilthyrius infiltrated the site.

Key Allies: Ayavah chastises the unholy fiends; Knud Helmarsson’s Horselords help you chase down and slay fiends who have escaped into the surrounding region.

Failure: Windsong Abbey is destroyed and an army of fiends swarm the land. If Runelord Xanderghul isn’t defeated in the next adventure, this smaller eruption triggers a greater breach into the Outer Rifts at the base of the Pit, just outside of Sandpoint, and a new Worldwound opens on Golarion.

Reward: For each obstacle the PCs overcome, award the group 20 XP, to a maximum of 120 XP if the characters complete all six obstacles. Saving the Saga Lands is a Mythic Deed that grants each character 3 Mythic Points, as long as they overcome more than 3 of the obstacles in this chase.

The Aftermath.name: The Aftermath
The Aftermath.text:
The Aftermath

After the Risen at each site are routed, the Doomsday Doors slam shut again, and the PCs and their allies can reconvene. This meeting is either a celebration (if all six doors were closed) or a discussion of how best to handle the devastation in areas where the Doomsday Doors were opened. The effects of any catastrophe released by a Doomsday Door are mentioned in the obstacles above, and while on a local scale these devastations are tragic, if Xanderghul can complete his tasks and become a god, they’ll be but a taste of what’s to come. The PCs have no time to personally see to these disasters if they wish to continue to oppose the root of this doom. At least for now, however, dealing with the fallout of these catastrophes is work for lower-level, non-mythic heroes. But before the PCs can even seriously consider challenging Runelord Xanderghul, they must work to ensure that killing him won’t just slow him down for a few moments.

Treasure: Word of the PCs’ heroism spreads quickly, and their allies organize and gather the funds and gifts of countless grateful inhabitants of the Saga Lands over the next few days. At some point before the PCs head into the dreamlands, Aethusa (or another allied NPC of your choice) contacts the PCs with the news that a powerful magic item reward awaits each of them. These items should each be 17th-level apex items (see pages 270–271 of Pathfinder GM Core for six examples). Work with each player to decide which of these apex items works best for their character. Beyond functioning as the apex item chosen, each item should be tailored and adjusted to, in some way, symbolize that PC’s mythic destiny.

The Bittersweet Sisters.name: The Bittersweet Sisters
The Bittersweet Sisters.text:
The Bittersweet Sisters

To prevent Liralarue from further assisting the PCs’ efforts to oppose Xanderghul, the Ashen Man imprisoned her in one of the prisons floating above the Oubliette Plains. Skeptical that the prison’s original jailor, a dramofir named Javownir, could be trusted to oversee such a powerful prisoner, the Ashen Man left three of his most trusted agents, a coven of moon hags known as the Bittersweet Sisters, in charge. Powerful oracles who once swore allegiance to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.WloVxo6HXJdS4YTt]{Groetus}, the Bittersweet Sisters agreed to serve the Ashen Man after learning of his recent successes. The Sisters grow impatient, however, waiting for Golarion’s destruction. To pass the time, they’ve begun freeing the nightmares previously imprisoned in the lower levels of Liralarue’s oubliette, although they’ve left Javownir alive, at least for now. The sisters aren’t aware that Liralarue has finally managed to send a psychic call for help, but they quickly realize (too late) what’s happened as soon as the PCs arrive.

When the party arrives, the Bittersweet Sisters are in separate areas of the oubliette. If the PCs keep them separated and defeat them one by one, the hags should be no match for a group of level 17 mythic characters. Once any of the hags detects intruders, however, she rushes to alert her sisters. Together, a battle with the Bittersweet Sisters is a Severe encounter.

Clever PCs can avoid a battle by using the oubliette’s spindle key in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3} to prevent the hags from joining forces—or at least make it more difficult by forcing them to Ride the Moonbeams between the levels. If the PCs make friendly contact with Javownir, he suggests this tactic to them.

Each of the Bittersweet Sisters—Aceta, Raanka, and Spleen—use identical statistics. Their individual tactics are noted in their corresponding areas of the oubliette.

Lower Point.name: Lower Point
Lower Point.text:
C2. Lower Point Low 17

The oubliette’s four anchor cables rise 400 feet from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03anchorpoint000]{C1} before disappearing into a 20-foot-wide opening in the oubliette’s lower tip. Javownir can telepathically command the maze-weavers in this area to retract the cables, thereby pulling the oubliette to the ground. The PCs can enter this area either by climbing through the opening from the outside or by descending the shaft from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}.

This chamber is an inverted pyramid whose sides slope at a precipitous angle toward a ten-foot-wide opening at the bottom. A shaft in the ceiling occupies the chamber’s eastern corner. Thick coils of webbing crisscross the sloped floor, all leading down to four thick cables of webbing that extend down from the opening in the floor.

The webbing on the floor here is not particularly sticky, so a creature can navigate the sloped floor of this room by Climbing with a @Check[athletics|dc:15|traits:move,skill,action:climb|name:Climb] check. If they fall, they slide toward the opening, where they can Grab an Edge (@Check[reflex|dc:36|traits:manipulate,action:grab-an-edge|name:Grab an Edge] save) to avoid plummeting to the ground 400 feet below.

C2. Lower Point Low 17

@UUID[Actor.5R0z7j2nKVkBjF53]{Maze-Weavers (4)}

Creatures: Assuming the PCs didn’t alert them while climbing from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03anchorpoint000]{C1}, the party encounters four maze-weavers here. The spiders fight to the death but refuse to leave the chamber, other than to investigate creatures climbing the anchor cables from below.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.0JpD2dSvYiUAvU54]{Corpses}
The long-dead bodies of many hapless intruders remain trapped and tangled in webbing here. A PC who spends 10 minutes searching them all makes a discovery—one of the bodies wears a suit of impenetrable scale armor.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
C3. Entrance Low 17

The oubliette’s gate is blocked by a portcullis made of high-grade adamantine (Hardness 35, 136 HP, BT 68). If the PCs spoke with Javownir via the speaking tube in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03anchorpoint000]{C1}, he might have already opened the portcullis by the time the party arrives. Otherwise, the portcullis can be Forced Open with a successful @Check[athletics|dc:35|traits:attack,skill,action:force-open|name:Force Open] check or simply bypassed with teleportation or similar magic. The spaces between the bars of the portcullis offer a view into the oubliette’s interior.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.2HmMzGzSfNY20HPK]{Toggle Portcullis}

This spacious area has three features of note. The first is a small building directly to the south of the gated entrance. At the east end of the room is a circular pit roughly ten feet in diameter, with an identical opening directly above it in the chamber’s ceiling. Finally, a formation of what appear to be soap bubbles grows from the chamber’s northwest corner. The bubbles stretch from floor to ceiling and extend roughly fifteen feet into the chamber. The surface of the bubbles glimmers with an oily iridescence.

The pit in the floor drops down into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2} but ends at a solid steel wall after going down for ten feet, as the steel separator between this area and area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03minimumsecur00]{C4} has been rotated 180º. Until the PCs use the spindle key (see area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03awardensoffi00]{C3a}) to realign the oubliette, physical access to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03minimumsecur00]{C4} from here remains blocked.

The “soap bubble” formation in the chamber’s northwest corner is a collection of prison cells used to contain animate nightmares. The nature of the bubble is a mystery even to Javownir: they grow directly from prison’s walls, changing in size and occasionally “popping” seemingly at random. The bubbles here are currently empty and can be smashed as easily as thin glass, though once a bubble contains an animate nightmare, it becomes incredibly more durable (as described in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03minimumsecur00]{C4}). For the purposes of determining line of sight and cover, assume a single 5-foot space filled with an empty bubble cell provides concealment and lesser cover, while a larger formation grants total cover and blocks line of sight completely.

C3. Entrance Low 17

@UUID[Actor.VdfyRzc4Pj1V5vfs]{Elder Shantaks (3)}

Creatures: Three ancient shantaks, used as mounts by the Bittersweet Sisters, pace about the chamber waiting for the Sisters’ orders. While these elder shantaks shrank down a bit as they grew older, they also developed a disorienting, mind-rending screech. The elder shantaks attack the PCs on sight and fight until destroyed.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.8xi81FowKb03Uda7]{Remains}
The shantaks often swoop out to hunt the Oubliette Planes for food, carrying back their meals to feed here. Bits and pieces of those remains lie strewn about the area, along with a fair amount of treasure. A PC who Searches the area for 10 minutes can gather up this treasure, which consists of a set of a major shining symbol, a +3 greater striking high-grade dawnsilver bastard sword, a wand of canticle of everlasting grief, and a dread blindfold still wrapped around a human skull that, somehow, has had all its meat (and brain) consumed without removing the blindfold.

Warden’s Office.name: Warden’s Office
Warden’s Office.text:
C3a. Warden’s Office Trivial 17

The building near the oubliette’s entrance serves as Javownir’s office and contains a writing desk, small bookcase, and comfortable sitting area. The lever that operates the portcullis, as well as the counterpart of the speaking horn in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03anchorpoint000]{C1}, are near the desk.

Creature: Javownir has been holed up in his office ever since the Bittersweet Sisters evicted him from his more spacious quarters in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03upperpointun00]{C8}. He’s currently trapped here by the elder shantaks in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}, who delight in tormenting him despite the Sisters’ orders to leave him alone. Once the PCs deal with the shantaks, Javownir cracks open the door to his office and hesitantly ushers the party inside.

Javownir is a mysterious creature known as a dramofir—an eerie being who feeds on dreams. Yet unlike most of his kind, Javownir long ago gave up the hunt to become the warden of this oubliette after feeling it call to him. The idea of imprisoning dreams and nightmares within such a strange prison appeals to the dramofir in a way he has difficulty explaining. Before the Bittersweet Sisters arrived with their prisoner, Javownir’s life was simple: every few weeks, nightmare hunting bounty hunters (sometimes fellow dramofirs, but usually denizens of Leng) would arrive to deliver an animate dream or animate nightmare to the prison. Less frequently, a prison containing one of these nightmares would break from its formation and float from the oubliette, drifting through the sky to parts unknown. In the times between, Javownir was left to spend his time reading or debating the nature of fear with the maze-weavers in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2}.

All this changed when the Bittersweet Sisters arrived. The Sisters commandeered Javownir’s quarters at the top of the spire (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03upperpointun00]{C8}) and repurposed them as a prison for Liralarue. The hags then fitted Javownir with an iron mask that fits over his snout and head like a close-fitting cage. It prevents him from escaping or using any of his occult abilities (including his occult innate spells). The mask would normally prevent speech as well, but since dramofir is telepathic, he bypasses this restriction (he still lives in fear that someone might counteract his constant truespeech spell, since he can’t re-cast it if this happens and will be unable to speak or understand language at all as long as the mask remains on).

If the PCs communicate with him, Javownir telepathically explains what he knows about the current situation in the oubliette. Though he can describe the Bittersweet Sisters, he knows nothing about their allegiance to the Ashen Man or Xanderghul’s attempts to destroy Golarion. He caught only a brief glimpse of the Sisters’ prisoner—a human woman with brown hair, wearing robes of purple and gold—but he suspects she must be a powerful spellcaster, as she was fitted with a mask like his own.

Though he’d like nothing more than to rid himself of the Bittersweet Sisters, Javownir hasn’t visited the oubliette’s other levels since the hags arrived, and he wouldn’t be much help against the Sisters in any case. He does, however, have one thing that might prove helpful to the party—but holds back on revealing this unless the PCs agree to remove his mask (see Bittersweet Mask below).

C3a. Warden’s Office Trivial 17

@UUID[Actor.AIsqKVhgC9LrQal4]{Javownir} @UUID[Actor.7EtywkFz8aRJB5Ap]{Bittersweet Mask}

If the PCs attack, Javownir fights back as best he can, but risks fleeing elsewhere into the oubliette if reduced below 100 Hit Points, hoping that the monsters and dangers in the other areas hurt the PCs more than him. If cornered, he offers his treasure to the PCs in exchange for his life, but if the PCs won’t treat with him, he has no recourse but to fight to the death.

Hazard: Javownir’s mask is a potent magic item, but not one that’s particularly beneficial, nor does it retain its power once removed from the one it’s been placed on. It functions more like a hazard from the PCs’ perspective. Removing the mask is a dangerous pursuit without the use of the mask’s key, which is currently carried by the eldest of the Bittersweet Sisters, Spleen (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7}). As it’s an attended object that Javownir can’t voluntarily drop, attempts to extract him by teleporting him out of the mask, turning him gaseous, shrinking him down, or the like also affect the mask and result in him remaining masked. If Javownir is killed, the mask detaches and loses its power, but even if the PCs promise to bring him back to life, the dramofir doesn’t trust them and will fight to defend himself if the PCs try this method.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.S1yQDD0pOEuTfeUF]{Drawers} @UUID[Actor.1kj0vVqvCnh3JVu0]{Shelf}
When the Bittersweet Sisters captured him, they destroyed what they thought was the only spindle key in the oubliette after using it to adjust a few of the steel separators to seal rooms up. They can use Ride the Moonbeams to teleport between levels and assumed that destroying the key would prevent Javownir or anyone else from opening the rooms back up.

In fact, a spare spindle key exists, hidden behind one of the drawers in Javownir’s desk. A PC who Seeks the desk and succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:36|traits:concentrate,secret,action:seek|name:Seek] discovers it, but if the PCs remove Javownir’s iron mask, the dramofir retrieves it and offers to loan the PCs the key. He even teaches them how to use it, granting them a +2 circumstance bonus to Occultism checks to solve the key’s puzzle. If none of the PCs can activate the key despite his help, Javownir can align the oubliette as requested, but this doesn’t allow the PCs to take advantage of the item’s other abilities. The dramofir impresses upon them that this is just a loan, and he expects the spindle key to be returned once the PCs are done with it.

The books on the shelf in his office are Javownir’s journals, most of which are devoted to lengthy descriptions of the various nightmares that have come and gone from the prison. The journals are written in Aklo, but contain no additional information of use to the PCs. Folded between two of the journals is a scroll of hidden mind, which Javownir offers to the PCs as a reward for removing the mask if they do so.

Reward: If the PCs remove Javownir’s mask and earn the spindle key as a reward, grant them XP as if they’d defeated Javownir in combat.

High-Security.name: High-Security
High-Security.text:
C6. High-Security Moderate 17

Hundreds, if not thousands, of bubbles grow from the walls of this chamber. In most places, the formations extend from floor-to-ceiling, dividing the chamber into a veritable maze.

The bubble cells on this level are identical to those on the minimum-security level. Animate nightmares of various shapes occupy a handful of cells throughout the area. Though none are quite so cute as the axolotls in area C6, while trapped in their cells, the animate nightmares appear as smaller, less intimidating versions of their true forms. None of these animate nightmares can be released from their bubble cells.

C6. High-Security Moderate 17

@UUID[Actor.DSlh2TFprPOVT6Sg]{Raanka} @UUID[Actor.Oq1o8ak2CzXnDMPv]{Plague Wolf}

Creatures: When the PCs first arrive on this level, Raanka, the middle Bittersweet Sister, strolls among the cells, admiring the nightmares trapped inside. She’s already managed to open one of the cells, and the shadowy, wolf-like creature with wings of smoke she let loose has bonded to her. Once she notices the PCs, both she and the wolf attack, relying on a combination of spells and stealth to conceal their locations. If it corners a lone PC, the animate nightmare casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.o4lRVTwSxnOOn5vl]{Sleep} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Jmxru8zMdYMRuO5n]{Vision of Death} or uses its Panicking Touch to inflict its plague effect. Once the opportunity exists, Raanka retreats to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7} to alert Spleen of intruders.

If Aceta escaped from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowsecurity000]{C5}, she joins Raanka and the nightmare in hunting the PCs, and this becomes a Severe encounter. Once they’re in danger of being defeated, the two hags flee to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7}.

Ch 3: Doorways to Dream and Doom.name: Ch 3: Doorways to Dream and Doom

Cults of Thassilon.name: Cults of Thassilon
Cults of Thassilon.text:
Cults of Thassilon

The religious landscape of Thassilon, both new and old, is as complex and multifaceted as the empire itself. The system and tradition of religious practices evolved throughout the empire’s history, shifting from a more classical model of faith serving alongside rulership at the dawn of the empire to an increasingly complicated model, blurring between the lines as the runelords gained more power. At its core were several prominent deities and powerful figures who shaped the spiritual landscape of Thassilon.

The Peacock Spirit.name: The Peacock Spirit
The Peacock Spirit.text:
The Peacock Spirit

Founded by Runelord Xanderghul, the Cult of the Peacock Spirit was a work of deception and vanity. After focusing his inner power and strength, Xanderghul positioned himself as a source of divine power, obscuring his role by creating the Peacock Spirit before he began spreading word of a new divine entity across Thassilon. In true prideful fashion, this new religion was a front to worship himself, with even other runelords remaining unaware that Xanderghul and the Peacock Spirit were one and the same.

Xanderghul was even able to enlist the help of all seven Runelords to construct his Grand Temple of the Peacock Spirit deep in the Kodar Mountains. As with the true identity of the Peacock Spirit, Xanderghul also neglected to tell the other Runelords and the followers of the Peacock Spirit that those who made the pilgrimage to the Grand Temple offered not only their prayers and supplications, but a small piece of their soul to fuel Xanderghul’s own mythic power.

Followers of the Peacock Spirit were generally scholars, ascetics, or those particularly interested in rune magic. A secretive church, many of the tenets remained a mystery to outsiders. The believers valued knowledge and the perfection of mind, body, and soul, and were generally viewed by outsiders as a self-absorbed cult—especially with their strong connection to the Runelord of Pride.

In addition to the church, Xanderghul founded two splinter groups—the Therassic Order and the Order of the Green Feather, which served as the right and left hands of the Peacock Spirit. The Therassic Order was a select group of monks charged with controlling and protecting the Therassic Library, safeguarding the secrets of the cult, while the Order of the Green Feather became the military arm of the religion.

The predominance of the Cult of the Peacock Spirit dwindled after the fall of Thassilon, though its influence remained, blending ancient history, magical research, and divine deception into a unique religious tradition. Today, the Cult of the Peacock Spirit has largely transformed into the Risen of the Trinity Star, though it’s too early to say what kind of impact the resurgence will have on Golarion.

The Shattered Hourglass.text:
The Shattered Hourglass

Roots of the Shattered Hourglass can be traced back to the early days of Thassilon, when the empire was still young and the runelords had not yet fully embraced their sinful specializations. This small coven of witches was led by the eerily ageless Maeve Dureskial—a woman who had visions of time distortions across Thassilon’s history. She foresaw the city of Xin-Edasseril becoming time locked, Runelord Karzoug using the Cyphergate to peer through time itself, and Runelord Alaznist meddling with time thousands of years later, yet these visions were so distorted and off-putting that she struggled with properly interpreting them. When she received a vision of Earthfall and the devastation it would bring to her homeland, her interest in temporal magic became an obsession.

Convinced that a set of temporal runes held the key to manipulating the flow of time, Maeve and her followers formed the Coven of the Shattered Hourglass. They believed that by mastering this occult magic, they could achieve immortality, foresee the future, and alter past events thereby giving them power over time. However, their pursuits came at a terrible cost to their sanity.

The cult organized itself into three circles representing the past, present, and future, though most of the coven believed the present to be an illusion—little more than the constantly changing transition point at which the past and future intersect. Members progressed through these circles as they demonstrated mastery, often aging rapidly or regressing to youth as an unintended side effect. Upon mastery of each circle, every member was branded with a magical tattoo symbolizing past, present, and future. These tattoos would often pulsate with energy, causing the skin around them to age rapidly and heal just as rapidly.

As the Coven of the Shattered Hourglass delved deeper into their studies, unsettling phenomena began to manifest around them. Members reported seeing shadowy figures that moved backwards through time, hearing whispers from their future selves, or experiencing moments of their own deaths only to snap back to the present. Some had their madness manifest in their physical forms, leaving their bodies young and vigorous, but their faces prematurely withered. The unluckiest would vanish entirely, only to reappear months or years later, babbling about futures that never came to pass. One member even found themself trapped in a temporal loop, endlessly replaying their most terror-filled moments.

When Earthfall struck, some members of the Shattered Hourglass were able to survive thanks to their manipulation of time. Eventually, the surviving members were able to return to the present timeline, though they found themselves displaced physically throughout Golarion, fueled by a singular goal of returning to the ruins of Thassilon to resume their studies. Many describe this persistent need as the “Coven’s Call,” a whispering voice in the back of their minds or the vision of a woman seemingly both young and old, just out of reach beckoning them forward. Those that deny the call to return are plagued with dreams of a deathless crone choking on her own tears until either they begin their pilgrimage or their minds break down under the strain. It’s rumored that both the vision and the deathless crone bear the visage of Maeve Dureskial, and that she still waits for her coven to return.

In the present era, the cult remains small and its members isolated, but they’ve opened their membership to be more inclusive of non-occult forms of magical study, particularly among practitioners of divine magic. A small sect worshipping the dragon gods Sarshallatu and Brixori found their fanatical views on the acquisition of knowledge and time aligned well with the cult. Other deities worshipped within the coven are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.vEMCpm7iidycRT5D]{Brigh}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.qqqrbq4uCrelQvgH]{Irori}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.9EKyWmjLUu42evxC]{Nethys}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QZD0u1jxwz0kj8uI]{Pharasma}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.3INt1X4ijBYnZYbU]{Shyka}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.lvCryIEcfy7XIbAc]{Ulon}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.SUaGdvQXxSAQAw03]{Yog-Sothoth}. The plethora of theologies represented herein has led to disagreements. Some seek to rewrite history to correct perceived wrongs or change outcomes of past events to their favor. Others are driven to uncover hidden truths about the nature of reality or attain personal power. One common thread among all members is their belief that, by controlling time, they might transcend mortal limitations and achieve a form of divine enlightenment.
The Shattered Hourglass.name: The Shattered Hourglass

Followers of Groetus.name: Followers of Groetus
Followers of Groetus.text:
Followers of Groetus

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.WloVxo6HXJdS4YTt]{Groetus}, the god of the End Times, manifests as a sentient, uncaring skull-faced moon looming ominously above @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QZD0u1jxwz0kj8uI]{Pharasma's} Boneyard in the Outer Sphere. His faith was active in ancient Thassilon, but his worshippers didn’t form into an organized church or formal hierarchy. Instead, they were a mix of solitary individuals or small, secretive groups united by their unwavering belief in the coming apocalypse.

The core tenet of Groetus worship is the acceptance, anticipation, and, occasionally, fervent desire for universal destruction. Followers typically wear gray robes adorned with blue accents, often unkempt and stained. Someone who willingly follows Groetus also willingly assumes the cost of disassociation and maddening visions, seen as a gift of their god. Many followers took it upon themselves to gather the beliefs and predictions held by these strange, scattered loners, collating their “dooms” into several tomes bearing the title The Book of the Last Moon. Yet, while these books shared the same title, their contents varied, as each gatherer held different opinions as to the most important of Groetus’s dooms. Today, it’s believed that no full copy of this text exists.

Three sects of Groetus followers held more power than the others in ancient Thassilon, and it is from them that the majority of the dooms cataloged in The Book of the Last Moon were gathered. These three followings were known as the Teeth of Oblivion, the Heralds of the Incarnate Moon, and the Followers of the Gray Sign.

The Teeth of Oblivion were true fanatics. They believed the world could end at any moment and lived their lives with reckless abandon. Their indulgent behavior often allied with various gods associated with undeath, though they balked at the idea of living forever as undead.

The Followers of the Gray Sign were almost congenial in comparison to most Groetans. Believing that he was simply a harbinger of the end times, rather than the destroyer, Followers of the Gray Sign were content to simply preach that the end is near and to do what they could to prepare others for this event. While less likely to commit acts that could hasten the end of the world, they were still a gloomy bunch.

The Heralds of the Incarnate Moon believed that the current world was corrupt and were simply waiting for the beginning of the next, pure world. They believed that Groetus would take the souls of the most powerful aside during the apocalypse, then use these souls to form the fundamental beings in the new world—and perhaps even elevate them to the role of that new world’s gods. By quickening the end of things, the Heralds hoped to hasten the end to bring about the arrival of their pristine new existence.

The leaders of the Heralds were powerful indeed, and as they built their cult into the most widespread and significant of Groetus’s sects, they turned to a frightening solution to hasten the start of the next world—the creation of a set of hidden portals they called the Doomsday Doors. Today, the sites of all but one of these ancient artifacts are lost, that one being located under the Lost Coast monastery known as Windsong Abbey. Yet many more of these dangerous relics remain hidden below the surface of the Saga Lands. The Heralds taught that the Doomsday Doors would herald the end of this world upon their opening, when they would unleash unspoken horrors, yet despite these doors cracking open for a moment during Earthfall, they have in large remained a disappointment to their creators. Though the sect passed on long ago, the Doomsday Doors they created remain, and are destined to play a significant role in the Revenge of the Runelords Adventure Path.

Order of the Starless Night.name: Order of the Starless Night
Order of the Starless Night.text:
Order of the Starless Night

In the early days of the Thassilonian Empire, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna's} worship was more openly practiced. The goddess of dreams, stars, travelers, and luck’s teachings was already well established among the native Varisians, and initially at least, much of those teachings aligned with the vision First King Xin held for Thassilon. Open worship declined significantly after the runelords rose to power, leading many Desnans to practice in secret, to modify her teachings to fit the changing landscape, or turn from the faith entirely. Those who worshipped in secret took to gathering in small groups at night to observe the celestial bodies and constellations and would leave butterfly imagery and iconography as a way to communicate their loyalty to the goddess.

Persecuted during the height of the runelord era of the Thassilonian Empire, some worshippers of Desna resorted to extremes to fight against the tyranny of the runelords. One Desnan priest lost his faith and beseeched the heavens for aid. The heavens didn’t answer, but a trickster known as the Ashen Man did. The Ashen Man gave the desperate Desnan an alien artifact known as the Void Mirror. Furious that a priest of Desna would betray his faith, the church of Desna turned against him, pursuing him as he fled south. As he fled, he used the Void Mirror, taking in aspects of the Dark Tapestry into his own soul. He was then possessed by an alien sentience called Tchekuth. The loyal Desnans defeated him, magically creating an earthquake that trapped him underground, and using the magic of the Void Mirror against him to keep him trapped. The victorious Desnans became the Order of the Starless Night, emboldened with a new credo to remain vigilant against alien threats. With Earthfall, however, the Order essentially went extinct.

Today, what remains of the Order’s legacy can be found scattered across western Avistan, including in southwest Ravounel, where the Order’s final battle against Tchekuth took place. Hints of their fight against other malevolences from the Dark Tapestry, particularly against the Dominion of the Black, now and then appear in ancient texts, carvings recovered magical items associated with withstanding alien manipulation, or in certain architectural flourishes found in some of the older monuments devoted to Desna’s worship.

Animate Nightmare.name: Animate Nightmare
Animate Nightmare.text:
Animate Nightmare

Whereas animate dreams form from the fears of specific individuals, animate nightmares are spawned by the terrors that beset civilizations. An animate nightmare’s appearance depends on the type of fear that created it, but, like fears, result in similar forms.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.3yq9O31OreSgxhux]{Animate Nightmare} Creature 17

  • uncommon
  • Large
  • Dream
  • Incorporeal

Emigrants from Dreams

Animate nightmares often haunt the ruins of the civilization that birthed them. Others are drawn to Jandelay, the enigmatic demiplane where the fragments of dead worlds are preserved for all eternity, or to Abaddon, where apocalyptic nihilism is the rule. These latter nightmares might stay close to their “parent” civilizations, while others wander the broken avenues of multiple worlds, feeding off the traces of fear that linger in those places.

Clockwork Whale.name: Clockwork Whale
Clockwork Whale.text:
Clockwork Whale

Out of all ancient Azlant’s clockwork creations, clockwork whales are perhaps the most impressive—or at least the among the largest. Shaped like a bizarre fusion of a shark and an enormous toothed whale, clockwork whales patrolled the shipping lanes around Azlant for centuries before Earthfall shattered the continent, sinking it beneath the waves. Outfitted with complex programming and sensory arrays that allowed for near-perfect navigation, clockwork whales are thought to have been used primarily for securing new and safe nautical routes, although some served as naval transports during Azlant’s cold war with the empire’s ancient enemy, the alghollthus.

With jaws nearly a third of its entire length, a clockwork whale’s bite can slice neatly through smaller seafaring vessels and inflict devastating damage to the hulls of larger ones. These gears swiftly cut those swallowed whole into fragments that are then slowly washed away by the flow of water through tiny gaps in the creature’s body.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.5vuhv7BQ7AsNCLXu]{Clockwork Whale} Creature 17

  • Rare
  • Gargantuan
  • Clockwork
  • Construct
  • Mindless

Winding Up

Most clockworks must be wound with a unique key by another creature. This takes 1 minute, after which the clockwork remains operational for the listed amount of time. As long as a clockwork whale spends at least a minute every day swimming, its self-winding ability allows it to continue operating without needing this step. A clockwork whale that can’t swim (as might be the case after a clockwork whale becomes beached) usually remains operational for approximately 8 hours before it completely winds down. Full rules for clockwork winding appear on page 70 of Monster Core 2.

Ravenous Crypt.name: Ravenous Crypt
Ravenous Crypt.text:
Ravenous Crypt

When tomb robbers loot the dead, sometimes the resting places of those victims animate to avenge them. This happens most frequently when the entombed person was a particularly greedy, gluttonous, or vindictive individual in life. Other ravenous crypts arise spontaneously in places where energy from the Void flows freely into other planes.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.VT3IYCG7bdDgZG3U]{Ravenous Crypt} Creature 14

  • Uncommon
  • Huge
  • Construct
  • Mindless

Boneyard Guardians

Ravenous crypts are occasionally encountered in the Boneyard, roaming that vast necropolis like packs of hungry dogs, although they quickly come to heel while in @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QZD0u1jxwz0kj8uI]{Pharasma's} presence. This behavior has led some scholars to posit that the constructs are created at the behest—or at least with the blessing—of the Lady of Graves. Magrim, the demigod of the dwarven afterlife, is also believed to have some connection to ravenous crypts, as suggested by the fact the pediments of many crypts are carved with the scowling visages of dwarven elders.

Peacock Phoenix.text:
Peacock Phoenix

Unlike its namesake, the peacock phoenix is a being of pure magic, a unique manifestation of Xanderghul’s alter ego as the Peacock Spirit.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.15TO8VpSxDgs10fh]{Peacock Phoenix} Creature 17

  • Unique
  • Gargantuan
  • Incorporeal
  • Mythic
  • Spirit

Other Mythic Phoenixes

Because it’s tied so intrinsically to Runelord Xanderghul and his alter ego, the Peacock Spirit, once the peacock phoenix is destroyed, it’s doubtful Golarion will ever see its like again. Whether different kinds of mythic phoenixes, born from similar confluences of magical and psychic energy, could ever exist remains uncertain.

Silent Devotee.name: Silent Devotee
Silent Devotee.text:
Silent Devotee

When the runelords first created the Emerald Chambers, an order of martial spellcasters was established to protect Xin’s tomb. Known as the Silent Devotees, members of this order cut out their own eyes and tongues in a gesture intended both to prove their devotion and to ensure that knowledge of the Emerald Chambers would never spread beyond the order. After an initial surge of volunteers, interest in the order waned once the duplicitous nature of the runelords (and rumors of their involvement in Xin’s assassination) came to light. Today, only a few dozen silent devotees remain.

The devotees expanded the scope of their mission after the runelords claimed portions of the Emerald Chambers for their personal use. These devotees fitted their empty eye sockets with emeralds magically imbued with the site plans for the Chambers, allowing them to patrol the extradimensional space in its entirety. Combined with the raw magic flowing through the Chambers, the emeralds turned the skin of the devotees a pallid green but also gifted them with a sort of immortality, such that the remaining devotees seem immune to the ravages of time. Today, the Silent Devotees are something more than the humans they once were.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.E3MQAayLHyz1Cgm9]{Silent Devotee} Creature 14

  • Rare
  • Medium
  • Humanoid

Xin-Undoros

The most devoted member of the Silent Devotees was surely Xin-Undoros, a loyal champion of Xin and one of the order’s first volunteers. Though he predicted Earthfall, Xin-Undoros failed to warn the runelords of the catastrophe, blaming them for the death of his beloved emperor. As punishment for this treachery, Xin-Undoros became a graveknight shortly after the end came. While this transformation returned Xin-Undoros’s ability to speak, he still refuses to do so, regarding such an act as a violation of his eternal oath.

Vogorond.name: Vogorond
Vogorond.text:
Vogorond

Vogoronds are the remains of destroyed worlds imbued with the beliefs, hopes, and memories of that world’s people. Their physical bodies often take the shape of monuments held dear by their worlds’ former inhabitants, such as a statue of a beloved monarch. Vogoronds are intelligent and often seek to see their destroyed worlds reborn. Because their consciousnesses are formed from millions or even billions of individuals, however, they rarely possess the reasoning needed to pursue their desires to an end.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.sUGjEmOq1cW5hK4D]{Vogorond} Creature 18

  • Rare
  • Huge
  • Construct

Reasoning with the Ruined Past

While a vogorond’s memories aren’t flawless, it knows more about its former world than any scholar could ever hope to learn. Often, a vogorond is the only remaining source of knowledge about the land it once inhabited. Theoretically, heroes from a world on the brink of destruction could travel forward in time to speak with a vogorond and learn what must be done to avert the apocalypse—an act which, paradoxically, would prevent the vogorond from being created in the first place.

Aethusa.name: Aethusa
Aethusa.text:
Aethusa The Thrice-Born Queen

For a person who would one day claim to be the reincarnation of not just one, but two, former runelords, Aethusa’s childhood was nothing if not ordinary. Born to a pair of administrators in the ancient Thassilonian nation of Edasseril, Aethusa was by all accounts a bright, obedient, but ultimately unexceptionable child. Though her lack of ambition was a constant source of worry for her parents, everyone assumed she would eventually follow in their footsteps, becoming a loyal soldier in Edasseril’s bureaucratic legions.

Whatever hope Aethusa’s family had for her future faded as she entered adolescence. At the age of 12, Aethusa cast aside traditional schooling, delving instead into the study of ancient history, obscure languages, and the rune magic of the runelords. When their daughter’s newfound passions proved unshakable, Aethusa’s parents suggested she enroll in one of Edasseril’s arcane academies, where at least she could receive a formal education in such matters. Even then Aethusa rebelled, insisting she could learn more—and more quickly—on her own. The conflict came to a head as Aethusa approached her 16th birthday, when she announced her interest in the runelords had been sparked by the conviction that her soul was the reincarnation of the two runelords who shared her name. Arguments that pointed out to her that the original Aethusas lived at the same time didn’t sway her convictions and only emboldened her to claim her soul was a merging of both previous lives. Together, Aethusa claimed, the three of them would one day rule not just over a tiny sliver of Thassilon, but the entire nation and beyond.

Disavowed by her family, Aethusa spent the next few years continuing her studies, mastering magic at a pace that seemed improbable for one who was merely self-taught. Soon, she’d gathered a coterie of followers around her, all of whom believed her claim as the successor of past runelords was neither an empty boast nor vain delusion. Though she showed a talent for rune magic of all kinds, Aethusa selected sloth as her focus, believing it to be the most expedient route to power. It was also during this time that Aethusa adopted the moniker of the Thrice-Born Queen: a nod to the runelords whose souls she shared, but also a declaration of her right to rule.

Aethusa’s ambitions would have eventually drawn the attention of the runelords themselves had Earthfall not intervened. When the apocalypse struck, Aethusa was in Xin-Edasseril and became trapped outside of time along with the rest of city’s inhabitants. In 4718 ar, when the crystal dome around Xin-Edasseril shattered, Aethusa emerged to a world where the dominion of the runelords had been interrupted, but not entirely erased. Wasting no time, she redoubled her efforts, and in a few short years had solidified herself as the leader of a growing movement to unseat both Runelord Belimarius and Queen Sorshen.

Whether Aethusa’s bid for power might have succeeded no longer matters, as several months ago, the voices Aethusa had heard since childhood began to urge her in a new direction. They compelled her to find Runelord Xanderghul’s runewell—and more specifically, the Eye of Arrogance, the extradimensional realm to which Xanderghul had retreated during Earthfall. When she arrived there, however, Aethusa realized that the voices in her head were no longer those of the other Aethusas. Rather, they were the whispers of the Ashen Man, an Ancient One intent on returning Xanderghul’s soul to the Universe, using Aethusa as his vessel, and now she struggles with the growing realization that it may well have been this mysterious entity manipulating her all along. Her memories of her time spent being possessed by Xanderghul are hazy and dreamlike.

Campaign Role

In Aethusa’s body, Xanderghul established a foothold in the Saga Lands, founded the Risen of the Trinity Star, reclaimed the Crypt of Sin, and created not only a small army of risen runelords, but also a brand-new body for himself. Aethusa can share this with the PCs, but at first, she has no reason to trust them. The most important bit of information she should share with the PCs is that she can still feel a link to Xanderghul, and that she knows if he dies or otherwise leaves his body, his soul can instantly take control of her again, over any distance. If the PCs explain what they’ve been up to and return her dagger and spellbooks, and help her to recover from her conditions, she’ll automatically trust them enough to do so, otherwise the PCs will need to work at bringing her initial attitude of unfriendly up to at least friendly.

Once she trusts the PCs, she can share what she knows with them, but her traumatic experiences (even after she physically recovers) prevent her from wishing to accompany the PCs on their adventures. She’ll travel with them, but as soon as she can, she hopes to find somewhere quiet to hide and continue to recover, mentally, from the ordeal. In the short term, her thirst for revenge against Xanderghul and her fear of being possessed by him again outweighs her desire for power—at least until the runelord’s plans are foiled. Additional ways in which Aethusa can aid the PCs are covered in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa]{Chapter 3} of this adventure, but left to her own devices, she prefers to retreat to a city like Riddleport, Magnimar, or Korvosa and, for the moment, wait and hope.

Aethusa’s stats below present her once she’s fully recovered from her ordeals and has reclaimed her dagger and spellbook (both found in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02commandcente00]{B18}); until she’s got her spellbook back and has a chance to rest and prepare, she has no spells prepared and must rely upon her cantrips.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.GUxewaLEqttNr7Hg]{Aethusa} Creature 15

  • Unique
  • Medium
  • Human
  • Humanoid

Terrors of Leng.name: Terrors of Leng
Terrors of Leng.text:
Terrors of Leng

Leng—the Nightmare Realm, the Terror Beyond Dreams, the Cold Wastes—the great mountain-bound, wind-swept plateau that surmounts the Dimension of Dreams is called many names and described in many ways. Perhaps none of them are truth; perhaps all of them are.

Myriad are the reports of this storied land, all told in hushed tones or only in broad daylight so as not to attract the attention of malevolent powers that might hold its secrets dear. In the waking world, little is known of this bleak plateau, for few travel there and even fewer return, but there are common threads among the stories spun about it. Almost all agree that Leng is a high, cold desert, desolate in all its aspects and bound on all sides by imposing mountains, save for its southern coast. Known as the Dreaming Shore, this southern reach is where Leng connects to the seas of the Dreamlands and is most accessible to those wanderers who seek it out, unwittingly intent on their own destruction.

At Leng’s northernmost extent, warded by strange, gargantuan statues (said to be capable of both vigilance and independent mobility) stands a mountain of unparalleled height called Kadath. Or perhaps it is a citadel, not a mountain. Perhaps it is both. Regardless, upon this impossible height are rumored to reside unknown gods of no known faiths, sequestered and guarded from intrusion by no less than the herald of primal chaos—sometimes called @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.3nxIpMGeCvcBIVov]{Nyarlathotep}, often known by other names. Surely, none who attempt to venture there return.

Leng is a realm seemingly devoid of inhabitants and yet is infested with countless mysterious and predatory dwellers. The mountains are stalked by such horrors as Leng spiders, scarlet walkers, and the disturbing, divine by-blow that people venerate as a sign of the inscrutable entities who reside within Kadath. The skies above these mountains are haunted by nightgaunts, known to fly in the voids both above and below the earth, as well as shantaks rumored to serve a hideous High-Priest Not To Be Described, said to spend their time piping mindlessly before a bottomless, shadow-veiled well within a prehistoric monastery. In the Underworld beneath the whole of Leng, teem and squirm and slither immense wormlike bholes, while entire cities of gugs and ghouls wage a futile, never-ending war of annihilation upon one another. Meanwhile, upon the wastes and its shores and within sparse settlements, like Sarkomand, dwell the Denizens of Leng, the realm’s ubiquitous natives and their masters and overlords, the loathsome moon-beasts of Nameless Rock.

It’s rumored that no less than three Great Old Ones called this land home: an entity known as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.FHZ2DZEJzjrPfyjH]{Mhar} rumored to be long dead—if such rumors are to be believed—and at least two other beings whose identities remain shrouded in mystery. The truth of this matter remains to be seen, but Mhar, at least, is spoken of on Golarion in relation to the great northern mountain of the same name, where it’s whispered that the Old One attempted to break free and enter the waking world. Rumors of this are further expounded on by talk that the denizens of Leng, at one time, attempted to create a device within the walls of the mountain to break through the very fabric of reality so they might call forth the horrors of Leng, or perhaps merely to bend time for some other nefarious purpose. The machinations of these folk are always inscrutable and not to be trusted.

Only the very foolish or the very unlucky find their paths have led them to the Terror Beyond Dreams, and few of those have survived to tell of it. Perhaps the most disturbing descriptions of the horrors found by these survivors are the reports that, in this realm, nightmares can take on life and become all too real.

A nightmare demiplane atop the Dreamlands, Leng appears to conform in many ways to the rules of that dimension, though it is, perhaps, touched on less frequently by wandering dreamers. Rather, it seems to be a domain more typically reached by intentional, physical travel within the Dreamlands to its southern shore and from there its haunted interior. Although only the truly lost or foolhardy would attempt such a thing.

Nightmares of the Plateau.name: Nightmares of the Plateau
Nightmares of the Plateau.text:
Nightmares of the Plateau

Many hazards exist within the seemingly lifeless steppe of Leng. They can be of any type, though environmental hazards unique to this locale are especially prevalent. Likewise, haunts exist as the remnants of luckless travelers, and malevolent inhabitants have their own propensity for setting cruel traps.

In addition, there is a type of hazard possibly unique to Leng: nightmare hazards. In many ways, nightmare hazards resemble a haunt, and the dire truth might not reveal itself to potential victims until they discover that attempts to disable it through exorcism are ineffective. As a result, these hazards tend to be some of the deadliest and most difficult to navigate in Leng. It’s not unheard of for a haunt to exist in proximity to a nightmare hazard as the remnant of some past victim or victims who fell prey to its dangers, nor is it for nightmare hazards to manifest on Golarion in areas where the boundary between the waking world and Leng have worn thin.
